results.title: His Girl Friday (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Cary Grant is the cheeky news editor, Rosalind Russell is the ace female reporter with printer’s ink in her veins. Amid the frenzy of newsmen competing for that front page story, high energy romance, and Ben Hecht’s famous overlapping dialogue and machine-gun paced script, a reporter about to get married and escape the newsworld, stumbles upon the biggest story of her career - a notorious criminal surrenders personally. One of the funniest and most biting screwball comedies on film. Also stars Ralph Bellamy. Based on the 1928 play “The Front page” by Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur and a remake of the 1931 Howard Hughes film “The Front page”.

results.title: His first climb
results.brief_description: Begins by showing basic climbing equipment, including boots, helmet, carabiner, chocks and ropes. Shows techniques such as the use of ropes, specific knots and the running relay. Stresses the need for three-point contact with rockface at all times and the necessity for an experienced instructor.

results.title: His fighting chance
results.brief_description: An account of the assistance being given to victims of poliomyelitis, showing techniques of medicine and rehabilitation schemes through which patients help to cure themselves.

results.title: Hiroshima & Nagasaki: the harvest of nuclear war
results.creator_credit: Iwanami Productions, Naoyuki Jinnouchi and Masami Hayakawa
results.brief_description: Outlines the horrific effects of the two atomic bombs dropped on the small cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in August 1945. With the aid of some contemporary footage, the film shows the devastating psychological and physiological results on the populace, both immediately and in the following months and years after the war. Includes footage of a visit by Pope John Paul II. Also mentions the huge stockpiling of thousands of far larger bombs in the decades since World War II.

results.title: Hiroko Ikoko
results.brief_description: Two little Japanese girls go for a stroll after school to look for beautiful tropical fish which they had been studying and drawing in school. Their search leads them to the pools of a formal garden and to the glass aquariums of street markets. Their parents, who have become anxious over their prolonged absence, go searching and find them. Many glimpses of Tokyo are seen.

results.title: Hirohito: the chrysanthemum throne
results.creator_credit: Nielsen-Ferns International, New York Times Productions and Jeremy Murray-Brown
results.brief_description: Examination of the Japanese emperor who, according to Shinto religion, is a direct descendant of the Sun God. Includes footage of Hirohito’s visit to England in 1921 and in the 1960’s; the signing of Japan’s conditions of surrender at the end of the war; and the American occupation after the war. Narrated by Henry Fonda. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Hiro: the Hiroshima generation
results.creator_credit: United Nations Television, Fuji-TV and Gilbert Lauzun
results.brief_description: While interviewing a Japanese student, the cameras show the diversity of Japan’s youth. Shows the clashes and the integration of foreign ideas as the young people struggle for an understanding of Japanese culture 25 years after the bomb.

results.title: Hinkler: the aviator
results.creator_credit: Nine Network, EBU, Penny Spence and John Armstrong
results.brief_description: Bert Hinkler became an Australian hero and is remembered as one of the world’s greatest avaitors. His record-breaking solo flight from England to Australia in 1928 was completed in 15 days reducing the original record by half. People wore Hinkler hats, Hinkler flowers, ate Hinkler puddings and had Hinkler dances as part of the excitement following this achievement. The program recreates scenes and uses archival footage to bring to life not only one of the greatest pioneers in aviation, but also a period of our history.
